Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Bermuda Seaweed Project
Award.AbstractNarration:
The islands of Bermuda are ideally located for the assessment of marine biodiversity because the isolated archipelago is at the interface of tropical and warm temperate zones, which harbor different floras and faunas. Bermuda's small size supports approximately 450 species of seaweeds; this number allows complete assessment of the archipelago's algal diversity over the period of the project. Using DNA sequence data, Bermudan species will be compared with specimens collected in Caribbean and North American habitats. The outcome will be the most comprehensive floristic survey for any island grouping.

The seaweeds that inhabit Bermuda are important as sentinels to changing water temperatures. Many tropical species that might otherwise thrive in Bermuda's waters cannot survive at the water temperatures reached during the winter. However, minor increases in minimum water temperatures around Bermuda may eliminate this obstacle. Warmer annual temperatures might also cause the disappearance of cold-water winter species. This study will result in an exhaustive baseline dataset of Bermuda's seaweeds that will allow detection of potential addition of tropical and loss of coldwater species from the flora. In partnership with local authorities, this project thus provides a critical resource for advance warning of ocean temperature changes near Bermuda. In addition, this project provides research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students and outreach to K-12 teachers and students and the general public through activities organized with the Bermuda Aquarium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Bermuda Seaweed Project proposed the molecular "barcoding" of red, green and brown algae of the entire coastline of Bermuda. During this project the DNA sequences from the nuclei, mitochondria and chloroplasts of all of the algae in the islands were collected to compare their sequences with related species on the tree of life (ToL). Each species is distinct by its molecular sequences of targeted genes similar to the zebra barcode seen on commercial products, and from this it can be aligned with its most closely related "barcoded" species. The sequencing work for this project was completed at the University of Rhode Island (URI). once the sequences were generated and compared with other known sequences in the genera they were found to represent, anatomical and morphological comaparisons were made to distinguish the characters that made separate species different in lab of my collaborator, Dr. Craig Schneider (Trinity College). On this basis, we could determine whether the species from Bermuda matched those of the same name from the Caribbean, Atlantic Europe, Mediterranean or elsewhwere.

Over the 4 year period, we sequenced over 1000 DNA samples from Bermuda for mitochondrial barcoding comparisons among the nearly 2000 specimens collected in Bermuda and more than 400 for ToL analysis (nuclear and chloroplast) for related species worldwide. My lab's focus was on molecular identification and comparison between species, to report results in the scientific literature, as well as to upload published sequences to two online databases, GenBank and BOLD, where data are shared with scientists who likewise need comparative sequences for their studies across the globe. Several species groups were targeted for this so-called molecular-assisted alpha taxonomy (MAAT), and many group analyses have been completed. Additional targeted complex genera and families are in the process of being published or studied, and will be finalized in the near future.

Since the beginning of the Bermuda Seaweed Project in 2011, we have published 12 peer-reviewed papers in top international journals covering algae such as the Journal of Phycology, Phycologia, European Journal of Phycology, Algae, Botanica Marina and Cryptogamie, Algologie. These papers outline the results of our work that show that a great number of species previously reported from Bermuda are not what they were previously identified as, rather, they represent new species mostly known only from Bermuda, hence endemic species to the islands. We described 34 new red and brown seaweed species in these papers, one new red algal genus, Archestenogramma, and one new red algal family, the Etheliaceae. Molecular data also revealed the presence of 13 seaweed species known elsewhere (mostly from the Caribbean Sea) but not previously known in Bermuda. As a result of all of these new findings, we have made a significant impact on the Bermuda, western Atlantic and tropical floras during the time period of this NSF grant.

One graduate student from URI defended her Ph.D. dissertation in the spring of 2015. She spent one year collecting samples in Bermuda, three years in my lab and one year in Dr. Schneider's Trinity College lab. During the past four years, I have trained six undergraduate students (two with funding from the grant, four with institutional funding) on the project, all of whom became proficient in MAAT techniques, and each has, or will, be part of co-authored publications stemming from their work in the lab on the Bermuda Seaweed Project. Two of these have entered graduate school in the STEM fields.
